bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, April 8, 1875

div1.p: Reed assures Emilie Lawrence of the sincerity of his feelings. She has not yet given an answer to his marriage proposal.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, April 8, 1875
div1.p:
Just as I was step-
ping on the cars at Blacks
& Whites, on my way to Harris-
onburg, your letter was han-
ded to me. A moment later the
train was rattling along at a
lively rate; but with all its
noise & jar was only a feeble
expression of the “commotion of
Emotions” in my own breast.
We had gone several miles, e're
I opened the envelope. What did
it contain? Within its simple
folds were there words that, like
fresh zephyrs, would bear
my spirit Heavenward, or
should I find nought but
cold, cheerless words, “such
as crush the life from out
young hearts”? These were
the questions that I asked myself.
But lo!, when opened, it contained
not the one nor the other! And yet
its message was dear to my
heart, since it was one of
truth & wisdom. Had you been
daily expecting such a letter,
as mine was, & had you an
hundred times revolved its
contents over in your mind, you
could not haven chosen thoughts
that would receive more surely
my admiration and approbation.
Did I tell you in my last letter
that I loved you? This one
shall repeat it a thousand
times. Would to Heaven it could
find an echo in your own
heart, whose “portals are
closed” against me! My only
prayer is that, e're another sun
shall sink into the sea,
you may find its “Key turned”.
Repressing my feelings, for the
moment, permit me to speak
a few plain words. You say,
“the question that you lay bare
to me is one that claims se-
rious reflection.” Most emphat-
tically does it require “serious
reflection,” and you may be
surprised to learn that it
is one to which I have giv-
en my thoughts, daily, for
many months past. It was not
the impulse of the moment that
caused me to tell you of my
love. No! no!- Had such been
the case, you would have known
it much sooner.

Consider, Miss Emilie, that I
am almost 24 years of age;
that during the past 6 years I
have seen something of the
affection which men & women
bear toward one another: (God
Knows, I must confess that I
have witnessed its absence of-
tener than its prescence;) that
during these years I have given
much thought to this subject;
that, living in the largest city
in America, I have seen & met
the most fascinating women;
and yet need I tell you that
you, & you alone, are the only
woman whom I have admired!
You say; “Still some, yea many,
but ask it (woman's love) to
soon scorn it.” Too true! Too
true!! But can you believe
that I ask your love for no
other love reason than simply that I
may scorn it? Could I but
see you for one hour- I know
that I could convince you of
my sincerity. Why, Miss Emilie,
the thought that most oppres-
ses me, that binds my tongue,
is the thought that I am utterly
unworthy of your love, nor
that I even can be worthy of it,
Whatever honors the future
should confer upon me.
I cannot invite you to luxury's
lap; to riches, nor to honors. I
can only invite you to a heart
as true to its word as is the
needle to the pole! For the
former I care but little; I
only desire that my lot may
be cast where I can find
some rest & “gather bliss
to see my fellows blessed.”
You exclaim; “there is no
chrystal purer than the affection
which she can bestow.” This I
cannot deny. Often have I seen
it as “pure as the chrystal”
& yet trampelled under foot!
Often have I, at such times,
thought, oh! could I but show
some woman what how great
affection man can bestow!
If her's is the chrystal, mine
should be the Sun to bring
to light its hidden defects!
For what were a chrystal
without the Sun? What were
the tenderness of woman's love
without the protection of
man's love?

You quote the words of the
Arrowsmith & you partic-
ularly emphasize “leaving all
things for the stranger,” and
add, “how often are we dis-
appointed in human nature
and discover, too late, that
we know them not.”

I acknowledge that I am com-
paratively a stranger to you
and that you know but little of my
disposition & character. But
there is such a thing as your my
becoming better acquainted
with me & there is an abun-
dance of time for this.
However happy & proud I
would be, did I know that you
had some affection for me,
and though life's burden would
be lighter, did I know that there
was a heart that would rejoice
at my success or console me
in my reverses; that there was
“an eye would mark my com-
ing & grow brighter when I
came”; still if it seem good
and proper, according to your
best judgement, to prescribe
certain conditions, or to make
certain requests, whereby I
may show to you may entire
sincerity, you have but
to say the word & then judge
according to my deserts-
I have been earnest & deter-
mined in some things during
my past years & I am deter-
mined in this: that I may con-
vince you, above the shadow of
doubt, that I bear to you the
purest affection, and to win
your love, if it be possible.
And, above all, I desire to
do this with an open heart &
Countenance! There is nothing
that I would not disclose
to your most searching exam-
ination, since to purposely
deceive a person whom we
love is, to me, the height of
repulsiveness- I trust that
I may soon hear from you
& may I hear “better things”!
My mother desires me to send
her best love to you.
div1.closer:
I remain, as ever,
your true friend, Walter Reed.
